observations.message: Variable scope bug in submit_review_verdict (real_mcp_server.py:5927-5929): current_idx, final_verdict, and phases accessed outside their definition scope. Lines 5927-5931 capture variables for SQLite update, but these are only defined inside the 'if should_finalize:' block (line 5826). If should_finalize is False, these variables don't exist when accessed at line 5928, causing UnboundLocalError.

The review finalization logic (lines 5826-5926) is deeply nested inside a conditional block, creating variable scope issues. Variables like current_idx, final_verdict, and phases should be defined earlier at function scope to avoid scope leakage bugs. This pattern is error-prone and causes reviewer agents to crash when submitting verdicts.

Recommend refactoring submit_review_verdict to extract finalization logic into a separate function. This would: (1) Fix scope issues by having clear input/output variables (2) Improve testability (3) Reduce function complexity (currently 200+ lines) (4) Make the code more maintainable. Consider: _finalize_review_verdict(registry, review_record, verdict_data) -> dict

Critical path failure: When reviewers submit verdicts, they crash due to this bug, blocking the entire review process. This breaks the enforced agentic review mechanism - the core feature preventing orchestrator self-approval. Without working reviewers, phase advancement is impossible, stalling all multi-phase tasks.

Test phase deliverable successfully met: Task was created, tracked properly with workspace structure (AGENT_REGISTRY.json, logs/, findings/, handovers/), and test agent completed with proper MCP protocol usage (reported finding, marked completion). The test successfully validated the orchestrator's agent deployment and tracking capabilities.

The test exposed a good pattern: Simple 'smoke test' tasks can catch integration bugs in complex workflows. Consider adding more minimal test cases like this for critical paths (agent spawning, review triggering, phase advancement) before implementing complex features. This test-first approach would have caught the scope bug before it affected real tasks.

Variables current_idx, final_verdict, and phases are defined inside 'if should_finalize:' block but accessed outside at lines 5927-5931, causing crashes when should_finalize is False. This breaks the entire enforced review mechanism - reviewers cannot complete their work, blocking phase advancement. ROOT CAUSE: Poor variable scoping in 200+ line function. FIX: Move variable definitions to function scope or refactor finalization into separate function. IMPACT: High - blocks all multi-phase task reviews. POSITIVE: Test phase successfully validated orchestrator agent deployment and tracking capabilities.
